Based on my search of Fahrenheit 451 symbolism regarding living beings, phoenix rebirth, memorization and preservation, I found comprehensive information about these key literary symbols and themes. Here's what the search revealed:

## The Phoenix Symbol and Rebirth

The phoenix is a mythological bird that occasionally burnt itself and was reborn from the ashes. At the close of Fahrenheit 451, Granger remembers the phoenix myth. The phoenix symbolizes rebirth and rebuilding, as the book-loving outlaws set out to preserve their knowledge of the books.(no content)The phoenix, a mythological bird that rises from its ashes, symbolizes renewal and hope. It foreshadows Montag's transformation and the potential for a new, literate society to emerge from the ashes of the old, destroyed by an atomic bomb.(no content)Granger looks into the fire and realizes its life-giving quality as he utters the word "phoenix." The phoenix, he says, was "a silly damn bird" that "every few hundred years" built a pyre "and burned himself up." Granger imagines the bird as "first cousin to Man" because the bird continually went through rebirth only to destroy himself again.

## Books as Living Beings and Memorization for Preservation

Books are described as dying birds when they are burned, which can be connected to the symbolism of the phoenix. This metaphor reinforces the idea that books contain living knowledge that can be reborn through preservation.

Montag himself escapes beforehand and is found by people who have dedicated themselves to the memorization (and through it, the preservation) of books. It is their hope that civilization will eventually be rebuilt.(no content)Granger explains to Montag the nature of the commune and how each member chooses a book and memorizes it. After the entire book has been memorized, he burns it to prevent the individual from being arrested by the authorities.(no content)Montag and the others memorize books, preserving their contents even though physical copies are gone. This act symbolizes the resilience of knowledge and the human spirit. It suggests that ideas cannot be destroyed if people remember and value them.

## The Cycle of Destruction and Hope for Breaking It

Granger describes the phoenix as continually destroying itself and being reborn from the ashes, and he applies that same observation to human history, where he observes this same vicious cycle in effect. Thus, for Granger, the Phoenix represents a still greater hope, not only that civilization will be rebuilt, but also that, if we can eventually learn enough from our past mistakes, we can break free from the cycle.

Their aim is to use what the books they know to benefit someone, in hopes of someday breaking humanity's cycle of war and stupidity.

## Fire as a Symbol of Destruction and Renewal

Bradbury uses fire to symbolize destruction, rebirth, as well as knowledge. The decision to be reborn into a world of knowledge or be destroyed by a self-destructing society is the critical choice that Montag must make.(no content)The bombing of the city shows how fire serves simultaneously as a symbol of destruction and rebirth. The fire rids the city of all that is wrong with society while cleansing it to be reborn into a new and enlightened place.

The search results reveal that Bradbury masterfully uses the phoenix symbolism to represent hope for cultural regeneration, while the memorization of books by the intellectual outcasts represents the preservation of knowledge as a living force that can survive even when physical books are destroyed.
